title: Pixel-to-cell renderer for framebuffer demos
body:
Motivation: Doom ports like doomgeneric expose a raw pixel framebuffer (e.g., 640x400). Terminal demos (doom-ascii) convert pixels to ASCII/block/braille with scaling and optional gradients. We need a reusable utility in termcat to do this efficiently.

Acceptance:
- Provide a utility (module or helper) that converts an RGB/RGBA or indexed pixel buffer to a termcat Buffer.
- Support at least ASCII + block/braille character sets with optional gradient mapping.
- Support integer scaling (e.g., 1x, 2x, 4x) to fit terminal sizes.
- Allow color on/off (monochrome fallback).
- Include basic tests for a tiny pixel pattern -> expected cells.

Refs:
- https://github.com/ozkl/doomgeneric (DG_ScreenBuffer)
- https://github.com/wojciech-graj/doom-ascii (ASCII/block/braille + scaling)

Fix bracketed paste edge case: naive pattern search

title: Decoder paste buffer growth can realloc a non-owned slice after alloc failure
Decoder paste buffer growth can realloc a non-owned slice after alloc failure
body: startPaste() sets paste_buf to an empty slice when allocator.alloc fails, but growPasteBuffer() later calls allocator.realloc(self.paste_buf, new_len) regardless. If the initial alloc failed, paste_buf is not owned by the allocator, so realloc is undefined behavior. Suggest: on first growth when paste_allocated==false, call alloc instead of realloc (or surface an error immediately on failed startPaste). Refs: src/input/decoder.zig:776-803.

title: Input.pollEvent treats WouldBlock as EOF
body: Input.readInput maps error.WouldBlock to 0, and pollEvent treats any bytes_read==0 as EOF (EndOfStream). With non-blocking reads, poll() can report readiness but read() still returns EAGAIN/WouldBlock, so this path turns transient no-data into a hard EOF. Suggest keeping WouldBlock distinct (propagate error or return a sentinel) and only treat an actual read() return of 0 as EOF. Refs: src/input/Input.zig:232-241 and src/input/Input.zig:329-338.

title: Renderer.resize can leave front/back buffers mismatched on allocation failure
Renderer.resize can leave front/back buffers mismatched on allocation failure
body: Renderer.resize resizes front then back. If back.resize fails (e.g., OOM), front has already been resized, leaving the renderer in an inconsistent state. Subsequent flush() assumes equal lengths and does @memcpy(self.front.cells, self.back.cells), which can read/write past the front buffer if sizes differ. Suggest resizing into temp buffers or resizing both with rollback (or guard flush with size checks). Refs: src/Renderer.zig:73-76 and src/Renderer.zig:111-112.

title: flushOutput drops/duplicates data on partial writes
flushOutput drops/duplicates data on partial writes
body:
In src/backend/posix.zig:430-437 and src/backend/windows.zig:310-330, flushOutput performs a single write/WriteConsoleA and returns error.PartialWrite if fewer bytes are written. The output buffer is not advanced, so retrying will duplicate the already-written prefix, and partial writes/EINTR are not handled.

Suggested fix: loop until all bytes are written (handling EINTR) or advance the buffer by the number of bytes written and retry on the remainder.

title: Blit/tile helpers to Plane bypass dirty tracking
Blit/tile helpers to Plane bypass dirty tracking
body:
In src/Blit.zig:68-77, 89-98, and 288-303, blitBufferToPlane/blitPlaneToPlane/tileBufferToPlane call dest.getBuffer() and write directly to the buffer without updating Plane.dirty_rect. With compositor auto dirty-tracking, these updates won't be collected after the initial full redraw unless the caller manually invalidates the plane, so blits can fail to appear.

Suggested fix: have the Plane-targeted blit/tile helpers mark the affected dest rect as dirty (or clearly document that callers must call Plane.markDirtyRect/compositor.invalidatePlane after blitting).

title: Compositor can emit orphan continuation cells when wide chars are clipped
Compositor can emit orphan continuation cells when wide chars are clipped
body:
In src/Compositor.zig:233-270, compositePlaneRegion copies cells verbatim and treats continuation cells (char == 0) as always non-transparent. When a plane is partially clipped (e.g., plane at x = -1 with a wide char at local x = 0), the visible region may include only the continuation cell. The compositor writes that continuation into the target buffer; the renderer then skips continuation cells, leaving stale characters on screen.

Suggested fix: detect orphan continuation cells created by clipping and replace them with a space/default cell (optionally preserving the base cell's style) instead of copying the continuation as-is.

title: POSIX pollEvent blocks on input and misses resize notifications
POSIX pollEvent blocks on input and misses resize notifications
body:
In src/backend/posix.zig:610-618, pollEvent checks the resize pipe once and then delegates to input_handler.pollEvent(timeout_ms), which only polls the input fd. If timeout_ms is null (blocking), a SIGWINCH writes to the resize pipe but does not wake the poll, so resize events are delayed until input arrives or a timeout is used. This breaks apps that rely on pollEvent(null) for immediate resize handling.

Suggested fix: include the resize pipe fd in the poll set (either in PosixBackend or by extending Input to accept extra fds) and surface a resize event as soon as the pipe is readable.

title: Buffer.setWideCell can wrap x+1 and write continuation to column 0
Buffer.setWideCell can wrap x+1 and write continuation to column 0
body:
In src/Buffer.zig:138-149, setWideCell checks `x + 1 >= self.width` using a u16 add. If a caller passes x == 65535, x + 1 wraps to 0, the bounds check passes, and the function writes a continuation cell at column 0 while the base cell is out of bounds. This corrupts the buffer and violates wide-char invariants.

Suggested fix: guard x >= self.width first and use saturating add (x +| 1) or an overflow check (x == std.math.maxInt(u16)) before accessing x + 1.

title: Input helper: key state smoothing for terminal repeats
Input helper: key state smoothing for terminal repeats
body:
Motivation: Doom-style movement expects key-down/key-up or at least stable held-key state. Terminals only deliver key press events (repeat varies by OS), which makes movement jittery. doom-ascii uses a key-press smoothing window.

Acceptance:
- Provide a helper that consumes termcat key events and exposes per-key held state.
- Configurable release timeout (e.g., key considered released if no repeat within N ms).
- Works with arrows + WASD + modifiers.
- Document usage for real-time demos.

Ref:
- doom-ascii -kpsmooth (https://github.com/wojciech-graj/doom-ascii)

title: macOS: demos ignore keyboard input
body:
Environment: macOS (Ghostty), running demos (e.g. ./zig-out/bin/input_logger or zig build demo).

Steps:
1) zig build
2) run a demo (input_logger/color_grid/demo)
3) press keys (e.g. q)

Actual: no key events are logged and the app never exits.
Expected: keypresses are delivered and q quits.

Root cause: PosixBackend opens /dev/tty and polls it for input. On macOS, poll(/dev/tty) returns POLLNVAL, so the input loop never reads from the tty and keystrokes stay queued (you can read them from the pty slave later). stdin is a pollable tty, but we weren’t using it.

Fix: when stdin is a tty, use it for input polling/reads while keeping /dev/tty for termios/raw mode + output. Updated PosixBackend to carry an input_fd, feed it to Input, and use it for poll/read.

Validation: pty harness now shows input_logger logs the q key and exits; color_grid exits on q; zig build test passes.

title: Dirty width mismatch for invalid UTF-8 in draw/print
Dirty width mismatch for invalid UTF-8 in draw/print
body: Dirty tracking in src/Plane.zig:456 and src/Terminal.zig:158 uses unicode.stringWidth (Utf8Iterator). Buffer.print uses a custom decoder that replaces invalid sequences and can consume bytes differently. If input contains invalid UTF-8, dirty width may under-report and leave stale cells. Expected: dirty tracking should use the same decoding rules as Buffer.print (or explicitly document/validate UTF-8).

title: Layout printWrapped undercounts rows when text ends with newline
Layout printWrapped undercounts rows when text ends with newline
body: In printWrapCharWithPos/printWrapWord, newline handling only bumps lines_used if the current line has content. If the input ends with a newline, rows_used excludes the final blank line even though the cursor advanced. Example: printWrapped(..., Hin, .char) returns 1 instead of 2. Suggest increment lines_used on newline unconditionally (or track a trailing-newline flag) so rows_used reflects consumed rows. Refs: src/Layout.zig:269-275 and src/Layout.zig:362-368.

title: Demo: Doom in the terminal (doomgeneric port)
Demo: Doom in the terminal (doomgeneric port)
body:
Build a Doom-in-terminal demo using doomgeneric as the engine and termcat for rendering/input.

Scope:
- Vendor or submodule doomgeneric C sources.
- Implement the doomgeneric platform hooks (DG_Init/DG_DrawFrame/DG_GetKey/DG_GetTicksMs/DG_SleepMs/DG_SetWindowTitle) using termcat.
- Render DG_ScreenBuffer via the pixel-to-cell renderer (issue termcat-2zs).
- Map keys to Doom actions; use key smoothing helper (termcat-q2k).
- Allow scaling + charset choice via CLI flags.
- WAD path via CLI; document shareware doom1.wad.
- No audio required initially.

Refs:
- https://github.com/ozkl/doomgeneric
- https://github.com/wojciech-graj/doom-ascii

title: Testing: escape timeout edge cases with split writes
Testing: escape timeout edge cases with split writes
body:
Current escape timeout tests write complete sequences in one shot (e.g., \x1b[A), which bypasses the timing ambiguity Input.pollEvent is meant to resolve.

Add tests that:
1. Write \x1b alone, wait >escape_timeout_ms, verify bare Escape event is emitted
2. Write \x1b, wait <escape_timeout_ms, write [A, verify Up arrow (not Escape + garbage)
3. Write \x1b, wait >escape_timeout_ms, write a, verify Escape then 'a' as separate events

This exercises the actual escape timeout disambiguation logic.

title: Blitting and sprite API with transparency
Blitting and sprite API with transparency
body: Add blit helpers to copy sub-rectangles between planes or from standalone cell buffers. Support transparent cells (no overwrite) to allow sprite-style overlays. Include options for tiling/repeat fill and clipping when source/dest exceed bounds. Provide tests for transparent holes, partial blits, and tiled fills.

title: Composition pipeline with dirty regions
body: Implement the compositor pass: walk planes in z-order, apply clipping, and compose into a scratch/back buffer with a notion of transparent cells (skip). Track per-plane dirty rectangles and coalesce into frame-level dirty regions passed to the renderer diff. Ensure plane move/resize/visibility changes correctly invalidate regions. Add tests for damage tracking and correct composition order.

title: Plane abstraction with z-order and clipping
Plane abstraction with z-order and clipping
body: Define a plane type wrapping a cell grid region with parent-relative origin/size. Support create/destroy, reorder (raise/lower), move/resize, and set visibility. Enforce clipping to parent bounds and track stacking order. Provide helper to translate between plane-local and screen coordinates. Add unit tests covering stacking, clipping, resize, and visibility toggles.

title: Rich compositor: layered planes and blitting
Rich compositor: layered planes and blitting
body: Introduce a lightweight compositor on top of the cell renderer: layered planes with z-ordering, clipping, and reusable blits/sprites so callers can compose UIs without manual full-screen redraws.

title: Windows console backend (ConPTY/Win32)
body: Add a Windows backend using Win32 console APIs or ConPTY. Support entering raw/unbuffered mode, translating key/mouse events into the shared event model, and writing color/attribute output with best-effort parity to POSIX. Document any capability gaps or behavioral differences.

title: Cursor updates do not trigger auto-present
body: In src/Terminal.zig:257, setCursor/showCursor/hideCursor update the renderer cursor but do not set Terminal.dirty or call maybeAutoPresent. In auto-present mode, cursor visibility/position changes are not flushed until a later draw/present. Expected: cursor updates should mark dirty or explicitly auto-present when auto_present is enabled.
